Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Methylene Blue-Assisted vs. Conventional Lymph Node Harvesting in Gastric Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomised using a centralized dynamic method

Participants.evidence: 60 patients with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the stomach, clinical stage I-III, and planned R0 resection with D1+ or D2 lymphadenectomy

Intervention.evidence: conventional versus methylene blue-assisted LN harvesting methods

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the efficiency and quality of conventional versus methylene blue-assisted LN harvesting methods.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the ratio of harvested LNs per minute, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomised using a centralized dynamic method

Number_Randomised.evidence: From August to December 2012, 60 patients were randomised: 29 to the conventional method and 31 to the methylene blue method.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All patients were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The methylene blue arm had a higher mean number of harvested LNs (43.4±13.9) compared to the conventional arm (33.6±11.9; p=0.005). The primary outcome ratio was also higher in the methylene blue arm (1.49±0.59 LNs/min) than in the conventional arm (1.12±0.46 LNs/min; p=0.010).
